title.narrative: Planning and Financial Management Capacity Building Program

description.narrative: Capacity in the Ministry of Finance strengthened for prudent, effective and accountable planning and management of public finances to promote growth and poverty reduction.

condition.narrative: Recipient has signed a contract with one FMO and an Adviser to the PIO
Recipient shall conduct capacity asseessment in Admin/IT Directorate and associated Advisers in first 6 months of effectiveness.Management support will be maintained or increased if necessary.
Recipient shall ensure that during the execution of the Project, at least one Procurement Adviser as agreed between both partieswill work under the Project
Recipient shall maintain Admin&IT Directorate in MoPF with functions substantially same to those in place at signing of Agreementand be responsible for overall implementation.
Recipient shall make its best efforts in signing a SoU with participating donors.
Recipient shall monitor and evaluate progress and prepare project reports in accordance with 4.08 of the General Conditions and onbasis of agreed indicators. Each report shall cover one trimester.
Recipient shall, by June of each year until project completion furnish detailed action plan for clearance for project components.
The recipient shall maintain until completion of the Project, a competent and qualified program implementation team comprised of aSenior Program Manager, a Senior Adviser Human Resources, and an FMO.

title.narrative: Fiscal discipline maintained through reduction in the non-oil deficit as a % of GDP.

baseline.value: Reduction in non-oil deficit (<100% of non-oil GDP) following moderation in spending growth for 2009 and 2010 State Budgets.

comment.narrative: Non-oil fiscal deficit as a % of non oil GDP in 2009 = 71.1

target.value: Reduction in non-oil deficit to <80% of non-oil GDP.

comment.narrative: Partially met. While dropping to roughly 80% and below 2011 and 2012, the deficit increased to 98% of non-oil GDP based on adownward revision to estimated 2013 non-oil GDP. Much of the volatility in this indicator stems from volatility and revisions tothe non-oil GDP figure.

actual.value: Non-oil fiscal deficit as a % of non oil GDP in 2010 = 71%Non-oil fiscal deficit as a % of non oil GDP in 2011 = 81.3%Non-oilfiscal deficit as a % of non oil GDP in 2012 = 78.5%Non-oil fiscal deficit as a % of non oil GDP in 2013 = 98%

comment.narrative: Partially met. While dropping to roughly 80% and below 2011 and 2012, the deficit increased to 98% of non-oil GDP based on adownward revision to estimated 2013 non-oil GDP. Much of the volatility in this indicator stems from volatility and revisions tothe non-oil GDP figure.

title.narrative: Budget with medium-term outlook submitted to Parliament on time.

baseline.value: 2010 Budget submitted on time as per Budget and Financial Management Law. Strengthen quality of forward estimates.

target.value: Continued timely submission of quality budget, and improved medium-term fiscal forecasts.

actual.value: Multi-year estimates of expenditure and revenue prepared based on macro framework. 2011-2014 budgets submitted to parliament 45days before end of fiscal year.

comment.narrative: This indicator is met.

title.narrative: Macroeconomic framework sets annual budget ceilings starting in 2009, with four staff able to update and interpret the framework byJuly 2011

baseline.value: A macro framework has started to set the annual budget ceilings. The model is gradually being updated and refined. At this stageit seems unlikely that four staff will be able to update and interpret the framework by July 2011

target.value: National staff able to update and interpret macro model and framework.

comment.narrative: Met (although staff not fully trained).

actual.value: Macro framework developed and is being used to establish fiscal ceilings and revenue envelope since 2011. Government staff are notable to fully manage the macro model.

comment.narrative: Met (although staff not fully trained).

title.narrative: Timely publication of audited annual financial accounts.

baseline.value: Annual Audited Accounts for 2008 are published as required though with some delay because of change in auditors

target.value: Publication of annual audited financial accounts within 30 days after its presentation to the Prime Minister.

comment.narrative: This indicator is partially met. Audited statements are prepared and submitted to Parliament, although with delay. Delays arecaused by late submission by the Ministry of Finance to the court of auditors, as well as delays in assessment there.

actual.value: Audited accounts for 2010 published on 4 November 2011Audited accounts for 2011 published on 11 December 2012.Audited accountsfor 2012 not published as of 31 December 2013.

comment.narrative: This indicator is partially met. Audited statements are prepared and submitted to Parliament, although with delay. Delays arecaused by late submission by the Ministry of Finance to the court of auditors, as well as delays in assessment there.

title.narrative: Completion of merit-based appointments across MOF and more than 75% are qualified staff.

baseline.value: Appointment of Grades A-B completed. Performance management system being developed.

target.value: More than 75% of positions occupied by qualified staff.

comment.narrative: Partially met. Starting from the top, senior management and grades A to C completed and competent. Grades D and E remain to bereviewed.

actual.value: Systematic evaluation of managers (both current and potential) led to replacement of a number of senior managers and appointmentofall managers and coordinators on performance contracts containing KPIs against 5 Year Operation Plan.Result: all managersreceived rating of satisfactory (C) or above in performance assessment in November 2013

comment.narrative: Partially met. Starting from the top, senior management and grades A to C completed and competent. Grades D and E remain to bereviewed.

title.narrative: Daily reconciliation of government bank accounts using FMIS.

baseline.value: Full reconciliation of accounts 2005-09 ($850mn in receipts and $800mn in payments).

target.value: Government accounts up to date and reconciled in FMIS.

comment.narrative: This indicator is partially met.Reconciliations with the central bank are happening, although with some delay.

actual.value: Bank reconciliations of the TSA still carried out within two weeks of the the close of each month. Government accounts incommercial banks not reconciled.

comment.narrative: This indicator is partially met.Reconciliations with the central bank are happening, although with some delay.

title.narrative: Institutional Development and Capacity Building Plan implemented and ongoing needs identified.

baseline.value: IDCBP implemented in part through MOF reorganization and merit-based appointment process. Agreed it will be finalised as part ofStrategic Plan process to December 2010.

target.value: IDCBP established as a sustainable and government wide approach to identifying and overcoming skills gaps among civil servants.

comment.narrative: This indicator is met. The IDCBP is considered the precursor to the Government Wide Human Capital Development Fund (HCDF)

actual.value: In early 2013, the ministry prepared a task and staff mapping analysis, and used it to determine skills gaps. It developed aformalprocess for identifying training needs, candidates and courses.In parallel, the government's professional development plan,the MoF component of which was supported by PFMCBPs PDP component, evolved into the government wide Human Capital Developent Fund.This fund, set up to support government wide training, drew heavily on the guidelines and processes established underPFMCBP.Merit-based recruitments to senior mangement positions in the ministry of finance were made based on assessments of coreand task specific skills required. Based on this, areas for development for successful candiates were identified, and now form partof individual training plans.

comment.narrative: This indicator is met.

title.narrative: Improved project supervision rating on implementation progress, procurement and financial management

baseline.value: Improvements in all aspects of program implementation though more work needed on FM, M&E, and reporting

target.value: Satisfactory ratings across all program implementation indicators.

comment.narrative: Met.

actual.value: Program management continued to strengthen through 2011-2012 with improved resource planning, consultant recruitment, and reporting.

title.narrative: Increasing domestic tax collections as a % of non-oil GDP

baseline.value: In 2009, domestic tax was 9% of non-oil GDP, an increase from 8% in 2007

target.value: Increasing domestic tax collections as a % of non-oil GDP

comment.narrative: Met. The increasing trend measured from 2010-2012 is evidence that this indicator is met.

actual.value: Domestic tax of non-oil GDP in 2010 = 5.4% Domestic tax of non-oil GDP in 2011 = 7.0% Domestic tax of non-oil GDP in 2012 =7.3%Domestic tax of non-oil GDP in 2013 = 9.5%

comment.narrative: Met. The increasing trend measured from 2010-2012 is evidence that this indicator is met.

title.narrative: Improving results from public perception surveys, for each Directorate, of efficiency, effectiveness, ethics and integrity

baseline.value: In 2010, first survey by Asia Foundation shows a poor public perception of Customs, slightly better for Revenue

target.value: Improving results from public perception surveys, for each Directorate, of efficiency, effectiveness, ethics and integrity

comment.narrative: Met. While not published, the Ministry has reacted strongly to survey findings, including engaging to improve training andregulation of customs brokers, and undertaking a port cargo time release study.

actual.value: Unpublished reults of a survey by a local think tank, find year on year improvements in the perception of corruption index relatedto interactions with government officials, notably at the Port.

comment.narrative: Met. While not published, the Ministry has reacted strongly to survey findings, including engaging to improve training andregulation of customs brokers, and undertaking a port cargo time release study.

title.narrative: Statistics Work Plan agreed by MoF and other stakeholders, with implementation plan agreed and funding secured by end-2010

baseline.value: Key elements of SWP being implemented (HIES, BAS and APS). Additional funding secured from other donors.

target.value: Completion of initial targets within the SWP.

comment.narrative: This indicator is met. The National Directorate of National Statistics has been elevated to a Directorate General of NationalStatistics. A survey calendar has been prepared that is more realistic than previous. In addition, an Annual Action Plan andProcurement Plan, as well as individual survey plans exist. Funding has been secured from the state FY14 budget, and donors tocarry out the survey plan.

actual.value: The annual SWP is being implemented which includes the release dates for trade, CPI, financial and other economic data. TheStatistics Directorate does not have a multi-year schedule of planned statistical and survey activities.

comment.narrative: This indicator is met.

title.narrative: Establishment and staffing of Legal Unit

baseline.value: Limited progress to date -- difficulty in finding suitably qualified staff. The Program has provided important in-line function.

target.value: Establishment and staffing of Legal Unit.

comment.narrative: Met. See detailed explanation above.

actual.value: New Organic Law established the Office of Legal Support headed by a manager at the level of Director General. A PFMCBP NationalAdviser was appointed as the Acting Coordinator, pending appointment of a qualified Unit Head. The Office of Legal Supportcurrently has 2 additional national staff. PFMCBP has two international legal advisers workign in this office, to support theoeprations of the unit. There is also services provided for commercial and businss lawyer, pro-bono by DLA Piper International.The Office of LegalSupport has provided in excess of 150 legal opinions in 2013, and issued 210 formal pieces of legal advice.

comment.narrative: Met

title.narrative: Establishment and staffing of Internal Audit Unit

target.value: Establishment and staffing of Internal Audit Unit.

comment.narrative: Met. See detailed explanation above.

actual.value: New Organic Law established the Office of Inspection and Audit headed by the manager at the equivalent level of Director General,supported by 4 staff (2 x Grade C, 1 x Grade D, 1 x Grade E). Audit Plan was prepared and approved by the Minister. At the timeof preparing this report - 8 investigations had been completed; 2 audits were underway; and, a number of additional investigationswere being undertaken. The Internal Audit Adviser was appointed supporting the staff within the Unit, providing capacity buildingandprofessional inputs.

comment.narrative: met

title.narrative: # Quarterly publication of budget execution reports within two months of the end of the quarter.

baseline.value: Reports have been submitted on time to Parliament.

target.value: Continued full functionality of Transparency Portal.

comment.narrative: This indicator is met. The transparency portal has been steadily improved, now including more data (e.g.execution rates by allclassifications), and with greater accessibility of reports (including full data downloads). Civil society used it to proposequestions for Parliamentarians during the budget debate.

actual.value: Quarterly reports in 2013 published within two months of the end of the quarter.

title.narrative: Aggregate revenue and expenditure outturn # 80% of budget in the last two years

baseline.value: Revenue outturn is over 90% in 2009, compared to around 75% in 2008. Expenditure outturn in 2009 is close to 90%.

target.value: Aggregate revenue and expenditure outturn at least 85% of budget in last two years.

comment.narrative: Partially met. While revenue has strongly overperformed, expenditure outturns have fallen below 85%. While execution of therecurrent budget remains above 95%, infrastructure spending has fallen following the completion of large projects, notablyelectrification. Lowering of budgets, and continued improvements to execution capacity are likely to mean overall execution ratesrise sharply to over 85% in 2014.

actual.value: Expenditure outturns for FY11 = 84% and in FY12 = 66%. FY13=66%Revenue outturns for FY11=140%, FY12 = 194%, FY13=100.6%

comment.narrative: Partially met (Revenue outturn systematically exceding targets, but expenditure outturn in FY12 below 80%, and remaining below,albeit closer to, 80% in 2013). Measures to improve budget credibility are taking effect, as budgets are reduced into line with(rising) spending capacity.

title.narrative: National accounts published by the Statistics Directorate and three staff trained as national accounts specialists by July 2011

baseline.value: Source data for national accounts being established, and efforts under way to appoint staff. SD have set April 2011 to publishnational accounts and GDP estimates

target.value: Source data for national accounts established; national accounts published; and three staff trained.

comment.narrative: Partially met (three staff trained, but not yet able to replicate).

actual.value: National accounts published for the period 2001 - 2011 based on improved expenditure and business activity statistics. Two staffmembers trained on basic elements of the national account compilation. This activity still needs significant external support.Offtrack to producing 2012 accounts due to consultant turnover.

comment.narrative: Partially met (staff not fully trained)
